qas.question: What is the attempt to understand other societies on their own terms?
What does accepting other cultures in their own terms moderate?
What can refer to both a methodology and the product of ethnographic research?
What is one of the foundational methods of social anthropology?
What is a needlessly complicated word which means "conceptual"?
What is cultural relativism guided by?
What moderates accepting other cultures on their own terms?
What is one of the foundational methods of Ethnology?
What does social anthropology involve the comarision of?

context: <b5_0>Inquiry in sociocultural anthropology<b5_0/> is guided in part by <a0_0>cultural relativism<a0_0/>, the attempt to understand other societies in terms of their own cultural symbols and values. Accepting other cultures in their own terms moderates <a1_0><b6_0>reductionism in cross-cultural comparison<a1_0/>.<b6_0/> This project is often accommodated in the field of ethnography. <a2_0>Ethnography<a2_0/> can refer to both a methodology and the product of ethnographic research, i.e. an ethnographic monograph. As methodology, ethnography is based upon long-term fieldwork within a community or other research site. <a3_0><b7_0>Participant observation<b7_0/><a3_0/> is one of the foundational methods of social and cultural anthropology. Ethnology involves the systematic comparison of <b8_0>different cultures<b8_0/>. The process of participant-observation can be especially helpful to understanding a culture from an <a4_0>emic<a4_0/> (conceptual, vs. etic, or technical) point of view.
